title: Acid-Base Titration
description: Determine the concentration of an unknown acid solution using a standard base solution. Master the art of precise measurements and endpoint detection.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Equipment
stepDetails.description: Set up the burette in the stand and rinse with distilled water, then with the NaOH solution. Fill the burette with 0.1M NaOH solution.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Sample
stepDetails.description: Using a pipette, transfer exactly 25.0mL of the unknown HCl solution into a clean conical flask.

stepDetails.title: Add Indicator
stepDetails.description: Add 2-3 drops of phenolphthalein indicator to the acid solution in the conical flask. Place on white tile for better endpoint visibility.

stepDetails.title: Initial Titration
stepDetails.description: Record the initial burette reading. Begin titrating by adding NaOH solution slowly while swirling the flask continuously.

stepDetails.title: Identify Endpoint
stepDetails.description: Continue adding NaOH drop by drop near the endpoint. The endpoint is reached when the solution turns permanently pale pink.

stepDetails.title: Calculate Concentration
stepDetails.description: Record the final burette reading and calculate the volume of NaOH used. Use the formula to determine the concentration of the HCl solution.

safetyInfo: Handle all chemicals with care. NaOH is caustic and can cause burns. HCl is corrosive. Always wear safety goggles and handle glassware carefully. Work in a well-ventilated area.

title: Chemical Equilibrium
description: Investigate Le Chatelier's principle by observing how changes in concentration, temperature, and pressure affect chemical equilibrium. Study the cobalt(II) chloride equilibrium system.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Solutions
stepDetails.description: 1. Take a test tube and add a small amount of cobalt chloride crystals. 2. Add distilled water slowly and stir until it dissolves. 3. You will see a pink solution because of the hydrated [Co(H₂O)₆]²⁺ complex.

stepDetails.title: Add Concentrated HCl
stepDetails.description: Slowly add drops of concentrated HCl to the cobalt solution. Observe the color change from pink to blue as the equilibrium shifts.

stepDetails.title: Dilute with Water
stepDetails.description: Add distilled water to the blue solution. Observe the color change back to pink as the equilibrium shifts in the reverse direction.

stepDetails.title: Temperature Effect - Heating
stepDetails.description: Heat the pink solution in a water bath. Observe how increased temperature affects the equilibrium position and color.

stepDetails.title: Temperature Effect - Cooling
stepDetails.description: Cool the heated solution in an ice bath. Observe how decreased temperature shifts the equilibrium back.

stepDetails.title: Record Observations
stepDetails.description: Document all color changes and relate them to Le Chatelier's principle. Calculate equilibrium constants where applicable.

safetyInfo: Concentrated HCl is highly corrosive. Cobalt compounds are toxic if ingested. Always wear safety goggles, gloves, and work in a well-ventilated area. Handle hot and cold solutions with appropriate equipment.
